cards.title: What the deuce! / The best of Wimbledon 2015

item.title: The best of Wimbledon 2015 — in pictures and quotes
item.trailText: As the climax of the tournament looms, we look back at the most dramatic and stunning photographs by the world’s best sports photographers
item.standFirst: As the climax of the tournament looms, we look back at the most dramatic and stunning photographs by the world’s best sports photographers

displayImages.caption: Novak Djokovic jumps after slipping on the grass during his semi-final against Richard Gasquet. Djokovic stands within one win of his third Wimbledon title after a 7-6, 6-4, 6-4 victory over the Frenchman, in a match the world No1 never looked in danger of losing. Photograph: Adrian Dennis/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Novak Djokovic jumps after slipping on the grass during his semi-final against Richard Gasquet. Djokovic stands within one win of his third Wimbledon title after a 7-6, 6-4, 6-4 victory over the Frenchman, in a match the world No1 never looked in danger of losing.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Novak Djokovic jumps after slipping on the grass during his semi-final against Richard Gasquet. Djokovic stands within one win of his third Wimbledon title after a 7-6, 6-4, 6-4 victory over the Frenchman, in a match the world No1 never looked in danger of losing.

displayImages.caption: A steward walks on to the court as Rafael Nadal warms up before his match against Thomaz Bellucci. The Spaniard was beaten in the second round by Dustin Brown, a German qualifier ranked at No102. After the defeat Nadal said: ‘I just need to accept these kind of things that can happen. I did all my career. Keep going. It’s not the end. It is a sad moment for me but life continues. My career, too. I have to keep going and working more than ever to try to change that dynamic.’ Photograph: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters
displayImages.altText: A steward walks on to the court as Rafael Nadal warms up before his match against Thomaz Bellucci. The Spaniard was beaten in the second round by Dustin Brown, a German qualifier ranked at No102. After the defeat Nadal said: ‘I just need to accept these kind of things that can happen. I did all my career. Keep going. It’s not the end. It is a sad moment for me but life continues. My career, too. I have to keep going and working more than ever to try to change that dynamic.’
displayImages.cleanCaption: A steward walks on to the court as Rafael Nadal warms up before his match against Thomaz Bellucci. displayImages.caption: Rafael Nadal shows poise as he serves during his match against Bellucci. After the defeat by Brown, the Spaniard added: ‘My motivation is to try to be back to that level. But if I don’t make that happen, actually I played five times here the last day, had the trophy back home two times, so it is not bad. At the end of the day, I lost. Don’t forget I played five finals here. I don’t know how many players did that.’ Photograph: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters

displayImages.caption: Sabine Lisicki returns to Timea Bacsinszky during their third-round match. Lisicki, the 2013 finalist, was beaten in two emphatic sets. Photograph: Adrian Dennis/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Sabine Lisicki returns to Timea Bacsinszky during their third-round match. Lisicki, the 2013 finalist, was beaten in two emphatic sets.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Sabine Lisicki returns to Timea Bacsinszky during their third-round match. Lisicki, the 2013 finalist, was beaten in two emphatic sets.

displayImages.caption: Nick Kyrgios hugs a ball boy in his match against Richard Gasquet. Kyrgios received a code violation for swearing during play. He raged at ‘external bullshit’. He rowed with the umpire over whether he was taking too long to change his socks. He hurled his racket 10ft into the air. The Australian appeared uninterested and in a sulk during one game, which provoked boos from the crowd. However, the player also won laughter when he broke off play to hug the ballboy on court. Photograph: Henry Browne/Reuters

displayImages.caption: The Australian Fanatics are quiet as they watch Nick Kyrgios lose to Gasquet. ‘You know, I’m not perfect out there. I’m going to have ups and downs,’ Kyrgios said after the defeat. ‘It’s the way you respond from that. I think it takes some serious balls to respond the way I did.’ Photograph: Adrian Dennis/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The Australian Fanatics are quiet as they watch Nick Kyrgios lose to Gasquet. ‘You know, I’m not perfect out there. I’m going to have ups and downs,’ Kyrgios said after the defeat. ‘It’s the way you respond from that. I think it takes some serious balls to respond the way I did.’

displayImages.caption: Heather Watson applauds the crowd as she leaves the court with Serena Williams. Watson pushed the five-times Wimbledon champion to the brink of a sensational defeat, only to be squeezed out by the American in a dramatic final set. ‘It was a tough, tough ask but I was super, super-close,’ the Briton said afterwards. ‘I think that’s what really hurts the most.’ Photograph: Adrian Dennis/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Heather Watson applauds the crowd as she leaves the court with Serena Williams. Watson pushed the five-times Wimbledon champion to the brink of a sensational defeat, only to be squeezed out by the American in a dramatic final set. ‘It was a tough, tough ask but I was super, super-close,’ the Briton said afterwards. ‘I think that’s what really hurts the most.’

displayImages.caption: Fans on Murray Mound react to the match between Heather Watson and Serena Williams. ‘What’s the toughest away match to play?’ Williams was asked afterwards. ‘A French player at Roland Garros? An Australian at the Rod Laver Arena?’ She did not think for long. ‘I’m going to have to go with playing Heather Watson in Great Britain, for sure.’ Photograph: Toby Melville/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Fans on Murray Mound react to the match between Heather Watson and Serena Williams. ‘What’s the toughest away match to play?’ Williams was asked afterwards. ‘A French player at Roland Garros? displayImages.caption: Vitalia Diatchenko of Russia serves during her match against Anna-Lena Friedsam of Germany as Zarina Diyas of Kazakhstan, foreground, prepares to play a shot as she takes on Flavia Pennetta of Italy. Photograph: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Vitalia Diatchenko of Russia serves during her match against Anna-Lena Friedsam of Germany as Zarina Diyas of Kazakhstan, foreground, prepares to play a shot as she takes on Flavia Pennetta of Italy.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Vitalia Diatchenko of Russia serves during her match against Anna-Lena Friedsam of Germany as Zarina Diyas of Kazakhstan, foreground, prepares to play a shot as she takes on Flavia Pennetta of Italy.

displayImages.caption: Roger Federer hits a shot through his legs during his match against Sam Querrey. From a sublime half-volley drop shot to one outrageous rally when, after over-running the ball, he lobbed Querrey with a between-the-legs forehand to win the point, Federer cut his opponent’s big game to pieces with a sublime performance. ‘I’m very happy with the way I’m playing,’ Federer said. ‘I’ve been playing well this season, really since here last year. It’s also a bit of a relief to be playing well at Wimbledon.’ Photograph: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters

displayImages.caption: Flavia Pennetta reacts after a point against Zarina Diyas during their first-round match on Court 10. Diyas won and was eventually knocked out in the fourth round by Maria Sharapova. Photograph: Justin Tallis/AFP
displayImages.altText: Flavia Pennetta reacts after a point against Zarina Diyas during their first-round match on Court 10. Diyas won and was eventually knocked out in the fourth round by Maria Sharapova.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Flavia Pennetta reacts after a point against Zarina Diyas during their first-round match on Court 10. Diyas won and was eventually knocked out in the fourth round by Maria Sharapova.

displayImages.caption: Novak Djokovic talks to a small bird on Centre Court during his match against Philipp Kohlschreiber. ‘From where I come from, from the capital of Serbia, Belgrade, there’s a special sparrow bird called jivjum. I believe this bird came all the way from Belgrade to help me,’ Djokovic said after his victory.  Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian
displayImages.altText: Novak Djokovic talks to a small bird on Centre Court during his match against Philipp Kohlschreiber. ‘From where I come from, from the capital of Serbia, Belgrade, there’s a special sparrow bird called jivjum. displayImages.caption: Benoît Paire kicks the line judge’s chair after losing a point during his second round match against Spain’s Roberto Bautista Agut. The Frenchman promptly received a warning from the umpire. Photograph: Adrian Dennis/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Benoît Paire kicks the line judge’s chair after losing a point during his second round match against Spain’s Roberto Bautista Agut. The Frenchman promptly received a warning from the umpire.
displayImages.cleanCaption: Benoît Paire kicks the line judge’s chair after losing a point during his second round match against Spain’s Roberto Bautista Agut. The Frenchman promptly received a warning from the umpire.

displayImages.caption: Dustin Brown returns against Taiwan’s Lu Yen-hsun during their first-round match. Brown sent Rafael Nadal crashing out in the second round. He reflected on his week: ‘When I’m in Jamaica at the end of the year, then I can have a Red Stripe and say, great. Great year, Dustin. You played great. There’s no time for that right now.’ Photograph: Glyn Kirk/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Dustin Brown returns against Taiwan’s Lu Yen-hsun during their first-round match. Brown sent Rafael Nadal crashing out in the second round. displayImages.caption: A spectator stands on a mobility scooter to watch the action on Court 16. Photograph: Suzanne Plunkett/Reuters
displayImages.altText: A spectator stands on a mobility scooter to watch the action on Court 16.
displayImages.cleanCaption: A spectator stands on a mobility scooter to watch the action on Court 16.

displayImages.caption: Serena Williams returns a forehand on Centre Court as she reached her first Wimbledon final since 2012. After she beat Maria Sharapova in the semi-finals, she said: ‘It’s never easy to beat such a great player who’s had such a wonderful career. Whenever you play someone that has beaten you before, you get really focused.’ Photograph: Adrian Dennis/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Serena Williams returns a forehand on Centre Court as she reached her first Wimbledon final since 2012. After she beat Maria Sharapova in the semi-finals, she said: ‘It’s never easy to beat such a great player who’s had such a wonderful career. Whenever you play someone that has beaten you before, you get really focused.’
displayImages.cleanCaption: Serena Williams returns a forehand on Centre Court as she reached her first Wimbledon final since 2012. Whenever you play someone that has beaten you before, you get really focused.’

displayImages.caption: Vasek Pospisil returns during his win against James Ward. He eventually lost to Andy Murray in the quarter-finals, a match in which he was given two time violations. He vented his frustration. ‘A lot of times these umpires, they seem to just want to be seen. I don’t know why they do it at a time like that. How many times do you see the top guys go more than [30 seconds] and they don’t get any violation, especially when it’s important moments? But I go out there and I get a time violation. I was right about to serve the ball. If he would have waited one second longer, I would have served.’ Photograph: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters

displayImages.caption: In another photograph by Stefan Wermuth, a player serves on Court 10 at a busy Wimbledon. Photograph: Stefan Wermuth/Reuters
displayImages.altText: In another photograph by Stefan Wermuth, a player serves on Court 10 at a busy Wimbledon.
displayImages.cleanCaption: In another photograph by Stefan Wermuth, a player serves on Court 10 at a busy Wimbledon.

displayImages.caption: Richard Gasquet fires a backhand against Novak Djokovic in their semi-final. Gasquet said afterwards that he had felt under pressure throughout because of the quality of the Djokovic return. ‘He never misses,’ he said. ‘All the time, you serve, you serve. The ball is always on your side again. It’s very difficult. You never make so many aces. He doesn’t make unforced errors. Even from the baseline he’s playing fast with a lot of aggression and takes the ball early. That’s why he’s the world No1.’ Photograph: Tom Jenkins for the Guardian

displayImages.caption: Slovenia’s Polona Hercog serves against US player Lauren Davis during their first-round match. Photograph: Leon Neal/AFP/Getty Images

displayImages.cleanCaption: Slovenia’s Polona Hercog serves against US player Lauren Davis during their first-round match.

displayImages.caption: Andy Murray talks to Roger Federer after losing to the Swiss player in the semi-finals. ‘At times I played some very good tennis and I served well – the best I had served in the tournament myself,’ said a downbeat Murray after the match. ‘All losses hurt, especially in the major events.’ Photograph: Toby Melville/Reuters

cards.title: In pictures / The many lives of Phillip Toledano
cards.rawTitle: The many lives of Phillip Toledano

item.title: The many lives of Phillip Toledano
item.trailText: We all wonder what the future holds, but Phillip Toledano took it a step further. He created a series of startling self-portraits in which he imagined how he might look in years to come
item.standFirst:
We all wonder what the future holds, but Phillip Toledano took it a step further. He created a series of startling self-portraits in which he imagined how he might look in years to come

Maybe by Phillip Toledano is published by Dewi Lewis at £30. To order a copy for £24, go to bookshop.theguardian.com

displayImages.caption: When photographer Phillip Toledano’s parents died, it wasn’t just their loss he felt, it was the loss of control. Rather than wait and see how his own future – his own ageing process – played out, he decided to confront each fear one by one. Here he imagines a life alone, with just a dog for company.  Photograph: Phillip Toledano
displayImages.altText: Old Phil and Doggie
displayImages.cleanCaption: When photographer Phillip Toledano’s parents died, it wasn’t just their loss he felt, it was the loss of control. Rather than wait and see how his own future – his own ageing process – played out, he decided to confront each fear one by one. Here he imagines a life alone, with just a dog for company.

displayImages.caption: Of this new project, Maybe, Toledano says: ‘Photography is always about the past. The moment a picture is taken, it’s behind us, in history. This project is about the future. But how do you research what has not yet occurred?’  Photograph: Phillip Toledano
displayImages.altText: Fat Phil
displayImages.cleanCaption: Of this new project, Maybe, Toledano says: ‘Photography is always about the past. The moment a picture is taken, it’s behind us, in history. This project is about the future. But how do you research what has not yet occurred?’

displayImages.caption: ‘As you go through life, you become accustomed to the way in which people look at you,’ Toledano says. ‘But when you suddenly jump from 45 to 95, and become an elderly man, people look at you very differently. You’re invisible.’  Photograph: Phillip Toledano
displayImages.altText: 92-year-old Phil, Florida
displayImages.cleanCaption: ‘As you go through life, you become accustomed to the way in which people look at you,’ Toledano says. ‘But when you suddenly jump from 45 to 95, and become an elderly man, people look at you very differently. You’re invisible.’

displayImages.caption: Each character entailed five hours of silicone prosthetics, which was physically difficult, but it was the emotional transformation that hit Toledano hardest. Here he envisages being homeless.  Photograph: Phillip Toledano
displayImages.altText: Old Phil Hobo
displayImages.cleanCaption: Each character entailed five hours of silicone prosthetics, which was physically difficult, but it was the emotional transformation that hit Toledano hardest. Here he envisages being homeless.

displayImages.caption:
‘I looked within,’ Toledano says. And then, with an acting coach and a prosthetics expert, he became each
one of his future selves… Photograph: Phillip Toledano
displayImages.altText: Birthday
displayImages.cleanCaption:
‘I looked within,’ Toledano says. And then, with an acting coach and a prosthetics expert, he became each
one of his future selves…

displayImages.caption: Toledano consulted fortune tellers, hypnotists, numerologists and palm readers to find out how his life might play out.  Photograph: Phillip Toledano
displayImages.altText: Old Phil Speaker
displayImages.cleanCaption: Toledano consulted fortune tellers, hypnotists, numerologists and palm readers to find out how his life might play out.

displayImages.caption: To see what the future might hold, Toledano began with a DNA test, and then the characters he would play started to form. ‘I would see myself as an old man. I would suffer a stroke; I would slip sideways… I would see my own death.’ Photograph: Phillip Toledano
displayImages.altText: Phil stroke
displayImages.cleanCaption: To see what the future might hold, Toledano began with a DNA test, and then the characters he would play started to form. ‘I would see myself as an old man. I would suffer a stroke; I would slip sideways… I would see my own death.’

displayImages.caption: Through the project Toledano learned a little about life, about how to die well, and a lot about himself. ‘I learned the value of not stuffing things away into the metaphorical attic, but rather looking them in the face.’  Photograph: Phillip Toledano
displayImages.altText: Suicide
displayImages.cleanCaption: Through the project Toledano learned a little about life, about how to die well, and a lot about himself. ‘I learned the value of not stuffing things away into the metaphorical attic, but rather looking them in the face.’

cards.title: In pictures / Raed Yassin's embroidered childhood memories

item.title: Raed Yassin's embroidered childhood memories
item.trailText: Beirut-born artist Raed Yassin’s family preserves memories of his childhood by stitching them into silk cloths with elaborate patterns
item.standFirst: During the Lebanese civil war in the 70s and 80s, photographs of birthdays and parties taken by Beirut-born artist Raed Yassin’s family were lost in the upheaval. He decided to preserve memories of his childhood by stitching them into silk cloths with elaborate patterns. Having grown up in a family of tailors, he opted for an artisanal method. “Silk is very fragile and delicate, which reflects the situation that I lived in and also the long Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk,” he says. It took two years to recreate the most haunting snapshots he remembered from the lost albums. The series is on show as part of the Shubbak festival in London from 13 July to 2 August

displayImages.caption:
Raed the Sindbad

“When I was a kid, my mum liked to dress me up like a cartoon character,” says Yassin. “It was too dangerous to go outside to the park to have fun, so she was having fun while entertaining me at home.”
displayImages.altText: artist Raed Yassin Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Raed the Sindbad

“When I was a kid, my mum liked to dress me up like a cartoon character,” says Yassin. “It was too dangerous to go outside to the park to have fun, so she was having fun while entertaining me at home.”

displayImages.caption:
Dancing

“That’s my, I think, fourth birthday. It was mostly just neighbours from the same building who came to these parties. I remember the photo, because I had a finger in my nose.”
displayImages.altText: Raed Yassin artist Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Dancing

“That’s my, I think, fourth birthday. It was mostly just neighbours from the same building who came to these parties. I remember the photo, because I had a finger in my nose.”

displayImages.caption:
In Baalbek

“Lebanon is a country where there are no camels, so this is really just a tourist attraction. I found it really funny that my aunt and uncle had that picture taken.”
displayImages.altText: Raed Yassin artist Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk
displayImages.cleanCaption:
In Baalbek

“Lebanon is a country where there are no camels, so this is really just a tourist attraction. I found it really funny that my aunt and uncle had that picture taken.”

displayImages.caption:
Raed smoking

“In the eighties, I don’t know why, parents liked taking photos of their kids holding a cigarette. It’s not lit, it was about pretending. But back then it was different, people used to smoke on the plane.”
displayImages.altText: Raed Yassin artist Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Raed smoking

“In the eighties, I don’t know why, parents liked taking photos of their kids holding a cigarette. It’s not lit, it was about pretending. But back then it was different, people used to smoke on the plane.”

displayImages.caption:
The birthday where nobody came

“We used to visit these two old neighbours a lot. During the civil war, people were closer to each other when they lived in the same place. It was dangerous to visit and this was one of their birthdays that nobody came to.”
displayImages.altText: Raed Yassin artist Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk
displayImages.cleanCaption:
The birthday where nobody came

“We used to visit these two old neighbours a lot. During the civil war, people were closer to each other when they lived in the same place. It was dangerous to visit and this was one of their birthdays that nobody came to.”

displayImages.caption:
Flying kid

“This is my uncle and my brother. If you look into Middle Eastern photography archives, you’ll see a lot of these pictures. Holding a baby like this was typical to show strength.”
displayImages.altText: Raed Yassin artist Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Flying kid

“This is my uncle and my brother. If you look into Middle Eastern photography archives, you’ll see a lot of these pictures. Holding a baby like this was typical to show strength.”

displayImages.caption:
By the sea

“This is a portrait of my family before I was born. It’s an image I always had in mind, because when I was five or six we couldn’t go to the sea even though Beirut is by the seaside, because it was too dangerous. It was a fantasy for me to go to the sea.”
displayImages.altText: Raed Yassin artist Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk
displayImages.cleanCaption:
By the sea

“This is a portrait of my family before I was born. It’s an image I always had in mind, because when I was five or six we couldn’t go to the sea even though Beirut is by the seaside, because it was too dangerous. It was a fantasy for me to go to the sea.”

displayImages.caption:
Dad in London

“This is in Trafalgar Square. Just my brother went on this trip with him, because I wasn’t born yet. I always envied my brother, because I couldn’t travel, so this photo has always stayed in my mind.”
displayImages.altText: Raed Yassin artist Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk
displayImages.cleanCaption:
Dad in London

“This is in Trafalgar Square. Just my brother went on this trip with him, because I wasn’t born yet. I always envied my brother, because I couldn’t travel, so this photo has always stayed in my mind.”

displayImages.caption:
Family portrait with peacock

“That was in the zoo in Saudi Arabia before I was born. My mum used to tell me how their life was much better before the war, so she also told me about this trip. I always remembered the Union Jack T-shirt on my brother, I don’t know where he got it.”
displayImages.altText: Raed Yassin Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk
displayImages.cleanCaption:

displayImages.caption:
The Christmas Eve

“My mum, who’s in the photo, always had some sort of entertainment for the kids. The beards are all made of cotton. They needed to be really creative back then, because there weren’t so many options to entertain your kids.”
displayImages.altText: Raed Yassin artist Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk

displayImages.caption:
Kissing

“That’s my mum and dad in the casino in the 60s. I think it was their first year of marriage. You can see that my mum was very shy, she was trying to pull back. My dad insisted on kissing her on camera.”

Paper bag mask

“Our neighbour used to play with me: she would draw something on a paper bag and make me wear it. My brother took this photo, but it was a weird moment for me. She was doing this project and I was her model... I remember it was something to do with birds.”

Imad Hamdi and his twin brother

“To be honest, I kind of made this up. My mum told me that they were once on a boat to Alexandria with [Egyptian actor] Imad Hamdi, and they took a photo with him. I thought I had seen the photo, but I couldn’t have: it was lost before I was born. But when I made this picture I was convinced I had seen it, because I had this image in my mind.”

“When I was a kid, my mum liked to dress me up like a cartoon character,” says Yassin. “It was too dangerous to go outside to the park to have fun, so she was having fun while entertaining me at home.”

image.caption:
Dancing

“That’s my, I think, fourth birthday. It was mostly just neighbours from the same building who came to these parties. I remember the photo, because I had a finger in my nose.”

image.caption:
In Baalbek

“Lebanon is a country where there are no camels, so this is really just a tourist attraction. I found it really funny that my aunt and uncle had that picture taken.”

image.cleanCaption:
In Baalbek

“Lebanon is a country where there are no camels, so this is really just a tourist attraction. I found it really funny that my aunt and uncle had that picture taken.”

image.caption:
Raed smoking

“In the eighties, I don’t know why, parents liked taking photos of their kids holding a cigarette. It’s not lit, it was about pretending. But back then it was different, people used to smoke on the plane.”
image.altText: Raed Yassin artist Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk

image.caption:
The birthday where nobody came

“We used to visit these two old neighbours a lot. During the civil war, people were closer to each other when they lived in the same place. It was dangerous to visit and this was one of their birthdays that nobody came to.”
image.altText: Raed Yassin artist Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk

image.caption:
Flying kid

“This is my uncle and my brother. If you look into Middle Eastern photography archives, you’ll see a lot of these pictures. Holding a baby like this was typical to show strength.”
image.altText: Raed Yassin artist Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk
image.cleanCaption:
Flying kid

“This is my uncle and my brother. If you look into Middle Eastern photography archives, you’ll see a lot of these pictures. Holding a baby like this was typical to show strength.”

image.caption:
By the sea

“This is a portrait of my family before I was born. It’s an image I always had in mind, because when I was five or six we couldn’t go to the sea even though Beirut is by the seaside, because it was too dangerous. It was a fantasy for me to go to the sea.”

image.caption:
Dad in London

“This is in Trafalgar Square. Just my brother went on this trip with him, because I wasn’t born yet. I always envied my brother, because I couldn’t travel, so this photo has always stayed in my mind.”
image.altText: Raed Yassin artist Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk
image.cleanCaption:
Dad in London

image.caption:
Family portrait with peacock

“That was in the zoo in Saudi Arabia before I was born. My mum used to tell me how their life was much better before the war, so she also told me about this trip. I always remembered the Union Jack T-shirt on my brother, I don’t know where he got it.”
image.altText: Raed Yassin Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk

image.caption:
The Christmas Eve

“My mum, who’s in the photo, always had some sort of entertainment for the kids. The beards are all made of cotton. They needed to be really creative back then, because there weren’t so many options to entertain your kids.”
image.altText: Raed Yassin artist Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk

image.caption:
Kissing

“That’s my mum and dad in the casino in the 60s. I think it was their first year of marriage. You can see that my mum was very shy, she was trying to pull back. My dad insisted on kissing her on camera.”
image.altText: Raed Yassin artist Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk

Kissing

image.caption:
Paper bag mask

“Our neighbour used to play with me: she would draw something on a paper bag and make me wear it. My brother took this photo, but it was a weird moment for me. She was doing this project and I was her model... I remember it was something to do with birds.”
image.altText: Raed Yassin artist Lebanese tradition of embroidery on silk

image.caption:
Imad Hamdi and his twin brother

“To be honest, I kind of made this up. My mum told me that they were once on a boat to Alexandria with [Egyptian actor] Imad Hamdi, and they took a photo with him. I thought I had seen the photo, but I couldn’t have: it was lost before I was born. But when I made this picture I was convinced I had seen it, because I had this image in my mind.”

item.title: The blitz: rare colour photographs
item.trailText: As the 75th anniversary of the blitz – Germany’s sustained bombing campaign of the UK in the second world war – approaches, these beautiful and striking pictures show the famous bombsites, the tin helmets, the victory rolls and the carry-on spirit
item.standFirst:
As the 75th anniversary of the blitz – Germany’s sustained bombing campaign of the UK in the second world war – approaches, these beautiful and striking pictures show the famous bombsites, the tin helmets, the victory rolls and the carry-on spirit

  • Blitzed Brits is at IWM North, Manchester, from 11 July to 10 April 2016

cards.rawTitle: Reviews of Ted 2, Dear White People, Love and Mercy, The Human Centipede 3

item.title: The Guardian film show: Ted 2, Dear White People, Love and Mercy, The Human Centipede 3
item.trailText: In this week's show, our critics review a comedy sequel, the end of a horror franchise, plus a race relations satire and a biopic of Brian Wilson
item.standFirst:
In this week's show, Xan Brooks, Peter Bradshaw and Henry Barnes review Paul Dano and John Cusack as Brian Wilson in Love and Mercy; the return of Seth MacFarlane's foul-mouthed teddy bear in Ted 2; Justin Simien's race satire Dear White People and the final instalment in the Human Centipede horror series. Plus, the team answer your questions, which you can paste in the comments below

• Don't fancy watching the full show? Here's standalone reviews of Ted 2, Love and Mercy, Dear White People and The Human Centipede 3
item.byline: Xan Brooks, Peter Bradshaw, Henry Barnes and Zoran Trajkovic

item.title: Tunisia gunman Seifeddine Rezgui on beach with Kalashnikov – new video footage
item.trailText: Chilling new footage has emerged of Tunisian gunman Seifeddine Rezgui walking along the beach with a Kalashnikov assault rifle
item.standFirst: Chilling new footage of Tunisian gunman Seifeddine Rezgui walking along the beach with a Kalashnikov assault rifle. The footage, published by the Czech Republic news website iDNES.cz, shows a close-up view of the man who went onto kill 38 tourists, including 30 Britons, in Sousse on 26 June
